Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Electrochemical sensors to detect pH, phosphate and heavy metals in water
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of inexpensive and reliable sensors to monitor multiple water quality parameters - pH, phosphate levels, and the heavy metals dissolved in water. These sensors are easy to use, portable, and can provide rapid test results. Most of the current technologies require water sample collection from sites, followed by tests in external labs. This technology can be used for residential and industrial applications. It can be used for monitoring water quality in swimming pools, residential and commercial aquariums, agricultural water run-off, water body with algae bloom, houses known to have lead service lines, industrial effluent, and breweries. Additionally, longer term development of the technology may enable integration with a plumbing system/water filtration system for automated monitoring and added reliability. <br/><br/>This I-Corps project has developed an electrochemical sensor using a screen-printed electrode modified with different functional nanomaterials to detect concentrations of dissolved heavy metals, phosphate and pH in water. In addition to graphene, functionalized nanomaterials and conducting polymer nanocomposites deposited on the electrode surface are a reliable approach to enhance the selectivity and affinity of target molecules of analysis. The nanocomposite materials include reduced graphene oxide and polypyrrole to increase the electron transfer and electrodeâ€™s surface area. The functional materials for the target molecules of pH, phosphate, and heavy metals are iridium oxide, molybdate, and cysteine, respectively. By observing the potentiometric and amperometric change occurring in the electrochemical reaction at the electrode-solution interface, quantitative and qualitative evaluations of the relevant substance in water are possible.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research team developed a portable, easy-to-use, rapid water quality detection system that can monitor multiple parameters such as pH, phosphate, and heavy metals from water samples. The project team conducted customer discovery, market research, and outreach activities to refine understanding on the demand and specifications of water quality monitoring systems.

The project has advanced the team's knowledge and understanding of the requirements for water quality monitoring systems from various customer sectors and their potential applications. It has also contributed to the determination of the specifications and functionalities of the water quality monitoring system, which can improve efficiency and accessibility for various customer groups requiring water quality monitoring. The project helped the team to identify key customer segments and market needs for water quality monitoring systems, which can guide the commercialization of the developed technology in its primary market.

Additionally, the project has provided valuable training and professional development opportunities to the project participants, including the principal investigator, the graduate and undergraduate students. The participants were exposed to various aspects of technology commercialization, such as customer discovery, market research, business model analysis, and outreach activities. The project has also enhanced their engineering skills and knowledge by involving them in the fabrication and testing of the water quality detection system.

The project has impacted the teaching and educational experiences of the project participants and other students by incorporating the lessons learned from the project into various courses. It has also increased social awareness and interest in water quality issues and solutions among the public.


Last Modified: 01/02/2024
Modified by: Woo Jin Chang
